Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
Pros: Very good photo quality, with about a full stop advantage over typical compact cameras at high sensitivities; Nice 5X zoom lens with 28 - 140 mm range; New and improved "hybrid" optical image stabilization; Well built, rangefinder-style body; Flip-out, rotating high resolution 2.8" LCD display -- good outdoor and low light visibility; Optical viewfinder; Snappy performance in most respects; Full manual controls, with support for RAW format; Smart Auto mode picks one of twenty-eight scene modes for you; Customizable menu, buttons, and spots on mode dial; Useful HDR, dynamic range, and shadow correction features; Powerful flash; Built-in neutral density filter and electronic level; Records movies at 720p (24 fps) with stereo sound and wind filter; Very expandable: supports an exter ... nal flash, remote shutter release, teleconverter lens, underwater case, and more; Above average battery life; HDMI output
Cons: Controls can be intimidating at first -- small and cluttered buttons, especially zoom and four-way controllers and shutter release button; Lens can be seen through optical viewfinder when at wide-angle position; Some redeye, though removal tool in playback mode got rid of it; Can't use optical zoom in movie mode -- 24 fps frame rate a bit choppy; Wish list: faster lens, WB bracketing, ability to set color temperature; No memory card included; can't access memory card slot while using a tripod; Full manual on CD-ROM
You'd expect great things from Canon's flagship compact camera and, in most respects, the PowerShot G12 delivers. It offers a solid (though somewhat cluttered) design, great photo quality, features for beginners and enthusiasts, HD video, and more optional extras than anything else in its class. Sure, a faster lens, further improved movie mode, and an actual printed manual would be nice, but I guess those will have to wait for the next model (or so I hope). For now, though, the PowerShot G12 is a good choice for those wanting near-D-SLR image quality, performance, and expandability in a more portable body. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
Pros: Articulated LCD screen helps compose from unusual angles High build quality Good grip Dials for ISO and EV New Front dial very handy Excellent optics with a 28mm start to the 5x optical zoom Excellent Optical Image Stabilization New hybrid IS system corrects for both lateral and angular shifts Good Macro Supports Raw (and Raw+JPEG) with less speed penalty than most Very good low light performance Excellent, familiar menu system My Menu for commonly used settings Custom settings on mode dial Good color accuracy Faster JPEG burst mode than G11 (but still sluggish) 720p HD movies with stereo sound Better than average noise performance Lots of accessories including an underwater housing, ring light, off-camera flash, teleconverter, fi ... lter adapter Optical viewfinder (but see Con about accuracy) i-Contrast with highlight and shadow adjustments Variable AF frame size AF-point zoom Tracking AF HDR mode (but requires use of tripod) Good flash range Decent flash recycling time Flash hotshoe Excellent battery life Face detection, face self-timer SDXC card support
Cons: Awkward size: heavy and bulky Controls are stiff and rough Small Shutter button and Zoom ring Mediocre cycle timesPoor optical viewfinder coverage High barrel distortion at wide-angle Moderately high chromatic aberration at wide-angle (when wide open)Moderate corner blurring at wide-angle (when wide open) Autofocus is slower than average at wide-angle, and on the slow side of average at telephoto No noise reduction options Optical zoom not supported during movies Telephoto doesn't go as long as some of the competition Auto flash can use slow shutter speedsLacking features some competitors have (no hand-held multi-shot modes, no automatic panorama feature, etc.)
_ When I last looked at Canon's G Series PowerShot, things were a lot simpler. The G10's competition was Panasonic's LX3 and Nikon's P6000. This time around, it's the Panasonic LX5 and the Nikon P7000 fighting it out with the Canon G12 as each company's flagship digicam. But there's a lot more competition for your camera dollar. Even from Canon, whose much more compact S95 may make you wonder which model is the flagship PowerShot. And beyond that, there are the mirrorless cameras from Sony, Panasonic, Olympus, and Samsung that are more compact than a dSLR if larger than a digicam, but offer better image quality than a digicam. The real debate this year isn't Canon, Nikon or Panasonic. It's more a question of how small you want the box to be and how large you need the sensor to be. On those counts, the Canon G12 would seem to be disadvantaged with a big body and a small sensor. The S95, like the LX5, has a very desirable small body but a small sensor, and the mirrorless cameras are bigger both in form and sensor. *Look and Feel*. So size is an issue. And if you're looking for a very small camera with excellent quality and full features, you might just fall in love with the S95. The Canon G12 is going to look too big to you and feel as heavy as a brick in your bag. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
The Canon PowerShot G12 is an advanced compact camera that can fit in your pocket, yet provides a full gamut of manual controls and a relatively big zoom. It's the type of camera you should consider if you want something that will give you full creative control and a flexible shooting range but without the bulk of a digital SLR and without the expense of an interchangeable lens camera.
Indeed, the Canon PowerShot G12 costs £539 and you don't have to change lenses to suit your shooting situation — it comes with a reasonably versatile 28-140mm zoom lens. However, the G12 does have some flaws; its image quality is a little too grainy for our liking, and its zoom lens exhibits plenty of barrel roll at wide angles. It could also use a better shutter button and more solid-feeling ... control buttons.
Canon PowerShot G12 versus PowerShot G11 versus PowerShot G10
The Canon PowerShot G12 replaces last year's PowerShot G11, which replaced the Canon PowerShot G10. The Canon PowerShot G11 had some notable differences with the PowerShot G10 (most prominently a 10-megapixel sensor on the G11 versus the 14-megapixel sensor on the G10), but the PowerShot G12 doesn't offer any significant advantages over the G11. It's very much an incremental upgrade that includes some fine-tuned adjustments to the overall offering.
In particular, the Canon PowerShot G12 can shoot in high-definition mode (1280x720 versus the G11's 640x480 video mode) and record stereo sound. The G12 has focus tracking, and it also offers a teensy bit more shooting speed compared to the G11 (up to 2 frames per second versus 1.3fps). The other main difference between the G12 and the G11 is that the G12 offers an expanded set of sensitivity settings: you can now select ISO levels such as 125, 160, 250, 320, 500, 640, 1000, 1250, 2000 and 2500.
A sample video shot at a Sydney Kings basketball game.
If you already own the G11, then apart from the features we've just rattled off the Canon PowerShot G12 won't offer anything that you haven't seen before. It has the same 10-megapixel, 1/1.7in CCD sensor, the same f/2.8, 28-140mm zoom lens and the physical features of the cameras are practically identical. There are dedicated dials for changing the exposure compensation, shutter speed, aperture value and ISO speed, and there are also buttons for changing quickly to macro mode, switching to manual focus and selecting a custom focus point. Another handy feature is the auto-exposure button, which, when pressed, changes to the optimal exposure settings regardless of the shooting mode you are in. It can be very useful if you're shooting in changing lighting conditions and haven't yet figured out the correct exposure settings manually.
A 2.8in, hinged LCD screen can be used to frame your photos, and there is also an optical viewfinder that can be used as a fallback if the conditions are too bright and you just want to get your bearings. However, the optical viewfinder doesn't reflect what is seen by the lens, nor does it show you the correct focus, so it doesn't give you an accurate representation of the frame you are about to capture. Basically, you'll always need to use the LCD screen.
The Canon PowerShot G12's body feels sturdy overall, but we hate its shutter button, which is too squishy and doesn't have a distinct two-step feel to it. The buttons on the rear also have a slightly cheap feel to them, but they are easy to press for the most part. We think the front dial for the aperture is a little too stiff; we'd prefer it to be looser, as moving the aperture one step up or down can be a little difficult.
Canon PowerShot G12: picture quality
The Canon PowerShot G12's picture quality is great overall. It can capture accurate colours and reasonably clear images, but it does suffer from noise, which becomes especially noticeable when you closely crop your photos. The bright f/2.8 lens means you can shoot with a relatively slow ISO speed in low-light conditions, which should help keep the noise down. If you choose any... expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: This camera is great for everybody. I am a pro that uses a pair of 1D Mark 3s and a 5D, and my girlfriend is a photographic novice. Next month she is touring France; so, I wanted her to take a camera that can shoot in Hi-Res RAW, jut so I can have the ability to really tweak her shots in case she composes something wonderful. She refuses to deal with my big, bulky DSLRs, and insists on a camera that will fit in her purse; so, a point-&-shoot is the only option. The Canon G12 really fits the bill. In casual situations she can turn the dials [Mode & ISO] to AUTO and always get a great shot indoors or at night. I'm teaching her to use the Manual, Time Value, Aperture Value, and Program modes for those more important shots of beautiful landscapes and famous landmarks, such as the Norma ... ndy Coast or the Eifel Tower. The G12 is setup like a DSLR in that it has almost all of the needed dials and buttons on the outside of the body for quick and easy location and use. No need to fumble through deep, multilayered menus in order to change your ISO, shutter speed or aperture. It even has an over/under exposure dial [+/- 2.0 in 1/3rd-stop increments] right on top of the box. it has a hot shoe for when she needs that extra burst of light, yet the built-in flash is more than adequate for most impromptu situations. The flip out screen is big and bright and flips-image when turned towards the subject. It also has an optical viewfinder [not a mini-LCD] that allows composing and shooting with the big screen off so you she can really extend your battery life on those long days away from AC outlets. Some other cool functions are Face Recognition, Subject Tracking, Blink Sensor, and Image Stabilization. Plus it shoots in HD-720p video. The only downsides are the lens' focal length, and JPG only in Auto mode; however, it will record in RAW in all manual modes. The Canon SX30 has a much better lens, but it does not record in RAW. Also, Adobe PhotoShop CS4 and PhotoShop Elements 8 [and earlier] cannot open the G12's CR2 RAW files without the use of Adobe's DNG Converter. PS -CS5 and Elements 9 with the latest Adobe camera RAW Plug-In Update [6.3] have no problems. For those non-PS users, the G12 comes with a disk of Canon's regular compliment of digital photo software that will work just fine. All in all, I love this camera. My girlfriend is already capturing images of professional quality, and now I have a point-&-shoot that lets me leave my DSLRs at home... sometimes. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
Pros: The Good: I took a brand new G12 on a two week trip through Europe, becoming familar with it on the flight over. Seriously. One thing that blew me away: The controls are almost exactly the same for various modes as my ancient A-1 from the 1970s!
That aside, low light capability is incredible - shooting yachts in Monte Carlo pre-dawn yield excellent results. The same for the interior of Blue Mosque and Haga Sophia in Istanbul. I used the adjustable LCD screen as the view finder while the camera was pointed straight up at the ceilings of St Peter's and the Vatican museum in Rome. The auto stabilization worked very well as I took video while walking.
I enjoy the size and feel of the camera, especially given my large hands. As a tourist, I enjoy using one device for photo ... s and videos. While the videos are not as good as my JVC HD, they are acceptable if you don't mind poor sound quality.
As others said, the auto efaults need tuned to keep the ISO from being forced unacceptably.
Cons: The Bad: Why does Canon insist on shipping a camera of this quality and price with a neck strap only? The hassle of finding a wrist strap torques me.
The Ugly: This camera, while good, should not be $500; this is unacceptable, and loses one egg.
Since my purchase a few months ago, I have used this camera on two vacations, as a guest in three weddings, and a few other family functions. I have other cameras, but the G12 has become my default. Once you adjust settings to your personal tastes it will achieve 90 - 95% of what I seek in a DSLR, save for very long focal lengths - which I rarely use these days.
I found the battery life very good assuming I didn't shoot video exclusively. I purchased a spare from a 3rd party at a reasonable cost and with a good life.
Also, I use no-loss image compression for outstanding prints.
If you can find this model on sale in the high $300 or low $400 range grab it. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: A wonderful experience! I am a photographer who shoots with quite a bit of different cameras - a view camera, polaroid, DSLR and a flip camera. The G12 has been, by far, the most enjoyable camera to work with. There is a lot of power in this small box. It is convenient and takes fabulous images. I love that it has excellent manual settings, variable formats for shooting and great video resolution. It's an awesome investment for photographers, and it's user friendly for those who want an excellent point and shoot!

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I've owned all Nikon products up till now. I compared products, read reviews & forums then decided on the G12 over the Nikon P7000. It's a great camera with alot of control options. The photos seem great on my Mac, though I haven't developed any yet. I give 4 instead of 5 stars because: 1. cannot shoot raw in auto setting 2. slow shutter has a cap of 15 seconds (Nikon & Panasonic go to 60 sec) 3. video is just ok. Everything else is great for me. I use the tilting screen more than I thought, battery life seems great, the chunky size has been more of a benefit than a hindrance. (I have big hands)

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
Pros: Features, Battery life, LCD screen
Cons: large, expensive
I purchased this camera from Best Buy while it was on sale and I am glad I did. I love the camera, but there are better camera's for only a little more than it's normal list price. I found this camera because I was looking for something better than a point and shoot and cheaper than a DSLR and for that this camera is perfect. My last camera was a Canon so the buttons and menus are all familiar to me, but I still think it would be manageable for someone without Canon background. As far as size, the camera does fit in some pockets, but if portability is a priority, look else where.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: Very glad I upgraded from G10. G12 moves my non-DSLR photography into new territory for low-light, HDR, and supported (non-tripod) shooting. Took it out to the Museum at sunset and easily caught awesome hand-held sunset and dusk scenes. Next, in the museum galleries I easily photoed historic artifacts in the very dim lighting using higher ISO settings 800-1600 with virtually no noise--a vast improvement over the G10 sensor! The articulated active LCD display (introduced on the G11) brought so many new angles to my shooting. I could place the camera against a wall for support and then virtually shoot over my shoulder or around a corner by twisting the LCD screen for viewing. This museum frowns on tripods, so the angled screen allowed me to still do supported shots at lower shutter speeds. O ... utside, with a short travel tripod, I twisted the LCD upward to comfortably compose my shots without bending or stooping--my knees and thighs thank you, Canon. Most of my shooting was done in Av or M mode. I also used the in-camera HDR bracketing/processing to turn out some nice JPEG HDR files of night time scenes that really showed what my eyes saw. Downside on the auto-HDR is that it is full automatic with no control over ISO, Aperture, or Shutter speed. You get what you get and I could find no facility to adjust exposure parameters for HDR shooting. Nevertheless, it is a useful capability and if I want more control I can always set up for exposure bracketing and post-process the scene outside the camera. Also, I think Canon has reached the limit on how many buttons/dials they can put on a small body. I found my fingers often mistakenly brushing buttons, leaving me to wonder what control I had invoked. I also had trouble feeling if my right index finger was on the zoom lever or the new front dial. Menus and LCD display controls are awesome--especially the new level indicator. I found myself constantly using the level. Overall, I found the G12 a great new advancement of the Canon G-series! Warning: Aperture 2 will not import G12 raws--you have to either upgrade to Aperture 3 or use the included Canon software to process the raw files. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: Prior to buying the G-12, I used the G-10 as my day-to-day camera. It is perfect for those times when it isn't practical to carry a DSLR with all the gear that goes along with it. My initial impression was that the G-12 didn't seem to be as rugged at the G-10, but I think that the rotating screen may have something to do with that. The few pictures that I have taken so far have been great. The low-light feature does an awesome job, though it does reduce the resolution significantly. Still, the shots are great for web. (I haven't printed one yet.) The few shots I have taken using the HDR have turned out well, though nothing compared to what can be done with software that gives the user more control. But, it is a nice feature to have, and I am looking forward to seeing just how much ... it can do. I am rating the camera a 5, and I still haven't even played with the HD video yet. This is a really nice camera, at a great price. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
What I think.
1. External Speedlite control - you still need a "Master" unit like a 580EX II or Canon STE2 to control external Speedlites. I almost considered going the Nikon route just to have that feature built in.
2. The screen is only 460K resolution. But very good.
3. The pathetic optical viewfinder. You are catering to those people that say a camera MUST have one of these - stop it. You are wasting space
4. The rear control wheel is too small - enlarge it so it feels more like one of your DSLRs.
5. While the lens is gorgeously sharp.
6. The lens needs to be wider - 24mm f/2 (or even f/1.8 in the Samsung) equiv is the primary reason I tried the LX5 and TL500 before going back to Canon.
7. No microphone input for video recording.
... 8. Just the right size - do not slim it down (and do NOT remove the articulating display).
So 8 things like that might sound like a big deal - but believe me when I say this - the camera is phenomenal.
Image quality is outstanding - I have had to process my RAW files with their converter (typically use Adobe Photoshop - but even with their converter image quality is second to none in the compact world. The lens is magnificently sharp. HD video results look pretty good - but not stellar. It'll do in a pinch - but its no camcorder replacement.
Operation speed is very very good. I have read a few posts saying that focusing speed is vastly improved from the G11 - I haven't found that to be the case but none-the-less its pretty good.
Construction quality is pretty good - but I love the rough textured finish more than the smooth finish on the G11 - it somehow makes it G11 feel cheaper.
Controls are absolutely second to none. Dedicated EV and ISO dials are wonderful. The new front control dial is great. The rear dial however could use a bit of an extension - hard to operate quickly with my fat thumb. kill the awful optical viewfinder.
Value for the money is mostly good - but if you are like me and need on-camera control of extern ... expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
Pros: Price versus Value
Cons: Not all filters will fit lens
After drooling over the camera for months on end, I bought one! The Best Buy price is the lowest during this special. On to the review!
I have a ten-year-old Sony Cybershot that is working great, but it is just at the end of its service life; the G12 is a hand-in-glove replacement. This camera feels very good; solid and weighty. If you are used to vintage 35MM optical SLR cameras, the transition is easy owing to the ergonomics the S12.
The battery must be charged before use and heed the instructions about depleting the battery before storage and charging it before a photo session.
Windows 7 (64 Bit) already has appropriate drivers in the OS. I did not install the software that came with the came ... ra. Other OS’s may require you do install Canon’s software.
The USB receptacle is a “human” type. I used an old USB cable from whatever. Of course, you can always pop out the memory card and use your reader port.
The photos are first rate and the zoom is more like a long focal length tele lens. I thought of getting a 1A Sky filter to protect the lens; Canon sells this filter. Other brands may not fit. Ditto: other accessories. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: 1 The lcd is fantastic, allows to take pictures or movie shoots in practical any position and situation, nice also when you are taking videos or do not want to be noticed when you are shooting, getting more spontaneous photos. 2 The ergonomic of the wheels for ISO,compensation and the mode selector are very well located, they work firmly. 3 The new front wheel, that works for increase or decrease the aperture or shutter speed is great. 4 The menu is easy to use and I like the new formats and sizes you can take pictures, 10:9, 4:3, 1:1, 3:2, 4:5 allows to get a better composition and photo formats without crop the image. 5 the rugged feel is nice for me, besides is only in two parts of the camera, where your hand and fingers needs more support. 6 At first instance I though the optical view ... finder appears to be so simple and awful like somebody told before, but, the diopter corrector works fine and when I clean the visor glasses, become so clear and nice that actually I am using it a lot, because do not need to open the lcd screen and it is possible to see the green or orange light which tells you that the exposition is ok or not, going back to the old times. 7 I did not test enough the video, but at first look, it is ok and allows to record some interesting moments. 8 The quality of the pictures is awesome, really love it, finally can get almost the quality I have with my DSLRs but in a small camera. 9 It is fast, is ready to take pictures maybe in a second. 10 The quality of the lcd screen may be is not the best, but, allows you to see if the picture is ok, and normally if you see that the picture is ok, when you opened in any software the picture is !really great! 11 for me all the wheels are well located, the buttons are in the right place, I have a normal hands size, use xl gloves, but have not fat fingers. 12 The autofocus works great, fast and with an excellent accuracy, feature not easy to find in a small camera, so reduces the possibility of loosing a nice photo. 12 Could be perfect, but nothing is. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: My usual cameras are DSLRs with heavier bodies and lenses. Sometimes I want to be a less serious photographer or just want to carry less equipment. The Canon G12 is a camera that is pocket sized and takes reasonable photos. The camera s only big negative is the viewfinder. It simply is too small to be usable. The G12 batttery life is short compared to my intermediate camera batteries. But usually I do not use flash with my other camers. I did use automatic flash with the G12 and that drains a battery more quickly. The Canon G12 would be a great camera for someone who wants to learn photography without spending a fortune but who wants to produce great shots. Controls are easy to find and use the manual is well written and camera features are best you can get in this price range.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I shoot video and stills with a Canon 5DMKII. I wanted a small coat pocket type camera for personal use. The G12 seems to be the best thing available in a compact camera. It's an evolution, not something new so reliability is proven. For still photography you can access full manual control--not as easily as with a DSLR but still pretty good once you get the hang of it. Video is unfortunately only 720p HD, but it is 24 frames per second, which is significant. I'll take lower resolution to keep within my 24 fps world over higher resolution at a different frame rate. Unfortunately, they cripple video functions and you do not have the same level of control as when shooting stills. You do have the internal ND filter, which is important, and you can lock focus and aperture to keep them from ... changing when shooting. However, manual aperture control is limited and in some conditions you are forced to shoot with auto aperture to maintain correct exposure. For home movies that's probably OK, but if you plan to get an occasional shot to include with more professional video, it is a problem. The lens is good and sharp and the camera has a heavy, solid feel. I've heard that lots of professional still photographers keep it in their coat pockets or purse for those situations where they don't want to take their big cameras, and that's a great use for it. Not quite so great for the videographer to do the same thing, but it is useful within its limitations. Battery life is excellent, and the optical viewfinder is useful sometimes, within limits. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
Pros: I have the venerable Powershot G2 from almost 10 years ago. Sensor is finally going (testament to its longevity) so I decided it was time for an upgrade. Not disappointed at all!
Fantastic functionality in a small package. While the lens is small (smaller than the G2), it is larger than most "point and shoot" cameras (better than phone lenses), and the sensor within is top notch. Great color reproduction. Fast - take a shot and while it is being previewed, tap the shutter button briefly and you are ready to shoot again. Auto white balance is great and offers a manual calibration mode to get the best colors from the environment you are shooting in.
Works great for underwater photos and video as well.
Cons: Auto functions? Honestly why bother including them ... on something like this. Do yourself a favor and learn the camera and shoot consistently on the "P"rogram mode (or other adjustable modes), and shoot with RAW.
Overall body has nice grip and weight, but honestly is a bit small to hold in large hands. I missed some of the bulk and flair to grip onto from the old G2. Solution: attach a tripod plate to the camera which offered decent finger grip on the underside. For others this will probably be a non-issue.
Glad I got it while it was discounted, but really, it's worth it's current price ($499).
As for the 4 egg rating - I really didn't dock an egg due to negativity of the camera. I just rarely trust overly gushing 5-star reviews. I tend to read the 4 and 3 star reviews and thought others may do more of the same. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: Quality- between big and P&S cameras
Item.Review: Remarkable image quality from a body far smaller and lighter than the big heavyweights; perfect for on-hip carrying without being bothersome, discrete without attracting attention in terms of presence. Swing-out LCD is extremely functional. Backside buttons awkwardly tiny, literally require a finger-nail push, not a finger. Very, very many built in functions; 212 page manual indicative, and Canon-characteristically... not always written with clarity. Movie capability remarkably good all things considered, but as with all cameras of the sort: holding it steady is difficult - relative lightness. Once familiar with grip-comfort and weight of full-size cameras, anything less is awkward. Compactness is excellent. Roughly 3X as heavy as a toy-type point&shoot and twice a big - well built and ... feels very solid. Proprietary battery, not AA's, but shooting-power capacity is most commendable. A well-seasoned product, has been around for years - a Classic is a worthy term, not simply the latest fad & fashion. Capable of professional-image shooting when in the hands of a skilled person. Carry-ability is its acclaim and major asset. For the person not familiar with typical camera controls, tweaks and adjustments the G12 is ill-suited to that person, though Auto-everything does work well. Zoom range is worthy, as is the camera-shake stabilizer. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
Pros: Size; Flexibility; Picture Quality; Control Design
Cons: Cost of excessories
You can't take advantage of photographic opportunities if you don't take your camera along. I found the G12 a perfect balance of small size and image accuracy. It protects itself well from casual contact with the world of shoulder bags and cargo pockets without a cumbersome case. I added the Canon FA-DC58B filter attachment and a UV filter to allow wandering around in the woods with the camera on without fear of lens damage. The filter attachment extends when you zoom in and retracts about half way when you zoom out again. The attachment does get in the way of the view finder, but again I'll take the compromise. If you're used to the way Canon organizes its menus you'll have no trouble learn ... ing the way this guy works. I don't need all the shooting options, the stuff like wink triggering or triggering when a face enters the frame, and I'm not going to be doing any videos here. So had I designed my perfect camera it would have a larger sensor and fewer whiz-bang shooting options. But I'm going to have a lot of fun exploring this guy. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: Pretty Decent Camera - Lots of Features
Item.Review: The camera is pretty easy to use right out of the box. Stick in a memory card and a charged battery, put in one of the auto modes, and you're good to go. But then I started reading the manual and discovered all sorts of features I might use one day. There's so much, it's scary. A wink-activated shutter? Ouchies! The main reasons I bought this camera are the flip out viewing screen, the RAW images it shoots, and the manual control. And it delivers on those counts quite well.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I wanted a smaller camera for travel and looked into the Canon G12. The reviews were helpful and were not wrong. Smaller size than a full body DSLR but same creative options. Love this camera! Very good in low light and the swing out rear screen allows for better low level shots.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I purchased the Canon G12 as a companion to my D-SLR for three main reasons: 1) I tend to mainly do Street Photography, and sometimes shooting with a large DSLR is too obvious and costs me shots when the subject notices my camera and shies away. 2) Some places (concert venues, etc.) prohibit entrance with anything they deem to be a Pro Camera - which usually means Any camera with a removable lens. I wanted a camera I could take in to such places while still getting high-quality shots in low-light conditions. 3) Sometimes I just don't want to lug around a heavy DSLR and lenses - but still want to shoot RAW and get great images. The Canon G12 has met and exceeded my desires and expectations in all categories! For Street Photography, I can mute all sounds, making the camera completely si ... lent (except for the sound of the zoom) and can shut off the Focus Assist Beam - providing me with a very discreet camera and the ability to shoot scenes without anyone knowing I am doing so. The auto-focus is fast and accurate... so I can trust the camera to deliver great shots, even from the hip. For low-light conditions this camera is amazing... providing results comparable to my Canon EOS 40D DSLR even at ISO 1600 - though anything higher than that and grain/noise does become noticeable in some situations. I tend to do 99.99% of my shooting relying on available light only, and have been very happy with the results I've been receiving. As a substitute for my DSLR, this camera is amazing! Though far from being tiny, this camera is quite compact considering how much is packed into that body. I find it comfortable to hold and use... and can easily slip it into a jacket pocket. The picture quality is wonderful, and - shooting RAW - I have full control over all settings using the provided Canon Digital Photo Professional software. I don't tend to shoot much video, but have done so once with the G12 and was amazed by the results. The image quality was fantastic... and the sound was amazingly clear. Bottom line: I'm in love with the Canon G12 and would highly recommend it! expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I am a TV journalist. I love photography. I like to take photographs about the stories that I cover. But my SLR camera is just too bulky for the job. G12 is giving me the opportunty to take manually adjusted RAW pictures and HD videos at the same time. I use the HD videos to support my stories too. In dangeros wor environments like Iraq the size and the ebilities are very helpful. Where ever I go I cary my G12. It is my new(s) body...I need a wider lens and 60 fraim per second Full HD option to be added in the future...

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: Could not be any happier! Great camera!
Item.Review: What a thrill! I have been looking for a point and shoot with top notch quality. I am spoiled with the results of my Canon T2i with a 24-105 L and 135 2.0 L (I use to shoot inside high school drama productions). Years ago I had the Canon G2 and thoroughly enjoyed it. When it died (lens stuck), I could not afford to remain in the G line, so I purchased various quality Canon point and shoots, ultimately using the SX110IS. I liked the fact i could replace the AA batteries while camping and hiking (I used lithium). But I hungered to return to the G line. I was holding out for the sequel to the G12, which turned out to be the GX1. But wholly molly they want an arm and a leg for it. I decided on the G12 because of price and I could not be more thrilled. The lens is L quality. The fea ... tures are more than I could have imagined. I bought an extra battery. One observation that bothers me is Canon does not include a wrist strap. Instead, the box has a shoulder strap. I prefer a wrist strap. I am using the strap from my mothballed SX110IS. Right out of the box I took the camera on a three-day boy scout snowmobile trip and came back with 650 priceless photos. I look forward to years of great photos with this camera. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: At it's new lower price, it can't be beat!
Item.Review:
Pros: well built. A lot of camera for little money (at current under $400 price).
Cons: really haven't found anything.
At it's new lower (under $400) price it is without question the best advanced point & shoot on the market. Larger sensor than most p&s cameras, fast, well built, can accept a hot shoe flash, swivel screen, HD video,ect... I mainly shoot with a DSLR but I wanted this for when I don't want to carry the bigger camera. I have not been unhappy with this camera. I have shot a few night photos at ISO 400 that are very clean (an area most p&s cameras fail). All in all, a great buy. Oh, and for what its worth, the reason the price has been lower lately is there is word on the internet of a "G" series replacement coming for this camera in a couple of months ... . However, from what I have read the new camera will be around $800 and the improvements over the G12 are minimal and in my opinion not worth twice the price of the G12. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: The G12 is a joy to use.
Item.Review:
Pros: Hot Shoe; Easy to adjust settings; Compact size; Easy To Use; Fast/accurate auto-focus; Multi angle LCD; Large Clear LCD; Short Lag Time; Good Image Quality; Small / Compact; Good Battery
Wonderful all around compact camera. Excellent image quality and controls. Easy to make adjustments. Flip out multiangle view screen. Would like to charge battery in camera but can live without that feature. Battery charges fast in external charger and provides good battery life. Great value at under $400. Fast turn on time. Adjustable built in flash plus hot shoe. I really am happy with this camera.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I am a professional photographer, and when I travel, I often bring two Nikon D700 with various lenses. The reason is that I was always afraid that I won't be able to take good quality photos. This year, I purchased Canon G12, and forced myself to bring this camera to my yearly European vacation. The torture of bringing big cameras is totally gone. The quality of the picture is pretty good as long as you do not use ISO higher than 640. I also purchased a radio remote control and a light Manfrotto tripod so that I can take picture of myself. I just do not like asking people to take picture of me, 99.9% people do not know how to take picture. You cannot use this camera if you really want to take serious high quality photos that you will blow up to a big size. But for vacationing, this came ... ra is MORE than enough. You can setup the camera like a real DSLR. As a result, you may totally be confused by the camera. This camera is not for a beginner who just want to do point and shoot. It is not easy to use this camera for those who do not know how to set up a camera. I do not recommend this camera for most people. You'd better off just by cheapo point and shoot. You can only take advantage of this camera, if you know how to setup a camera. Otherwise, you will just waste your money. Even I sometimes need to think how to set up certain thing. Again, it is not an easy camera to setup. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I've had it only a few weeks but I have given it a rigorous workout. It's pretty quick to start up, continous shooting is acceptable and the pictures are of good quality. The controls are easy to work and there are many different options. I used some of the automatic settings at times simply because I didn't have much time to get really familar with the camera and they usually yieled good results. I especially liked the My Colors feature and I found the ND filter to be handy. I had read other reviews where they said the flash wasn't strong enough. I found it to be pretty strong and did not use my external, which I had carried with me. In fact, I had to power the flash down some. I used the low light setting a lot and was surprisingly pleased with the results. There was the occasio ... nal photo that had noticeable noise, but not too many. The only negative I thought was battery life. It really stinks. With the Canon battery, I got less than 200 shots. I had also bought a Pearstone brand as a backup battery and that lasted as long as the Canon one. When the battery starts to go-you'd better change it quick! All in all, it was the perfect camera for the trip I took where I didn't want to lug around my DSLR and lenses, etc. I don't regret purchasing it. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: Fantabulous as a second camera with SLR as first..
Item.Review:
Pros: Quality of photos and manual control and flip out screen
Cons: Nada
I actually read quite a few reviews on this camera. It has exceeded my expectations... The video was the focus with most of the reviews I read. A lot of people were not happy with the video... I also have a 60D. So video on the G12 was not an issue for me. I desired a small camera with excellent photo quality for those times I do not wish to lug around a larger camera. Anyhoooooo... It is an excellent smaller camera...

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I am a former 35mm (film)camera user. For the past number of years, I have been using a small point & shoot, never really being satisfied with its diversity. The G12 has proven to be the answer for me. It is small enough to easily transport. Having the settings on the outside of the camera allows quicker manipulation. Auto setting is wonderful. Perfect pictures n low light. I also love the movable screen. Only change I would make is the power of the zoom, but I can live without it.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I am an amature photographer. I have both a Nikon D90 and a D7000 which I like very much for serious photogrophy However, the Canon G12 allows me to put it in my pocket for quick snap shots while traveling. I have been amazed at the range of the lens and the clarity of the pictures. I have had the camera for a short period of time and I am still experimenting with all of the many possabilities available in the camera. It took me a while to get used to using the screen positions since I am used to the direct view finder. I tried the view finder on the G12, but I found it a little small and difficult to use. It is a pretty sophisticated little camera for its size. I haven't tried the movie option yet. Looking forward to that.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: Canon Provides a little camera which provides almost any manual setting you are used from an SLR. As a loyal SLR user I found most of the dials and buttons easy to use and very handy too. Most of the new mini cameras come with several manual settings embedded in their software. It is either very hard to find the right settings from complicated menus and hidden submenus. Canon G12 though, has everything underneath your fingertips. Makes changing controls and setting easily and fast while shooting as real photographer. Lens and the zoom range it provides quite competitive with its competitors and not too greedy either. G12 gives you the feeling of a professional touch on the design and outcomes while still small enough to carry in your pocket or your purse. I must say it is slightly heavier ... than similar mid range compact cameras, but considering opportunities it provides, totally worth it. One last note, flip-LCD screen was more handy than I thought it would be. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: Good News = It shoots RAW Easy to use Bad News = Zoom is weak. Picture quality in low light is weak. Can't Focus during video mode. Kinda bulky for a point and shoot. Big price for these setbacks.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I was undecided on what small camera would be best for traveling not wanting to carry the big canon w/lenses and accesories. I tried several but being old school need a viewfinder and like RAW capability. The B & H salesperson suggested the G12. Having bought from B & H before I trusted the sales person after he said he bought the same camera for his father for the same reasons. I love it, its small (one handed operation) shoots RAW, has all the manual capabilities, is lightweight, and with the adapter can take filters which is something wanted. It is a great little camera and plan to pack it on all my trips rather than the bulky SLR that I have missed so many shots with getting it out and set. The screen is a good double check for settings and light, but the viewfinged makes me ... feel like I am using a real camera rather than a toy. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I am a Canon shooter. A while back when I was in search for a camera to supplement my Canon 7D, for the times that I didn't feel like lugging a bunch of stuff around, I decided to buy the Canon S95. At that time I looked at the G12 and decided that it was simply too big. I thought to myself, if i'm gonna lug that around then I may as well take my SLR. Fast forward. Unfortunately, the S95 died. It fell victim to the dreaded Lens Error problem that I think several others have encountered. Being that i was away from home, and no able to go through the warranty to have it replaced I was soon in the market for another camera to supplement my DSLR. After looking at several other Canon Point an shoots, I found myself missing the quality of the S95. That was when I locked eyes on the G12, ... and it was love at first shot. After a few test shots in the store, I was shocked by the image quality and ergonomic design. There is a button and dial for everything. The layout of the camera is as good or better than any I've used. The image quality is excellent and the RAW capability is something that i really like having for the pics that i want to work over with software (LR, PS, Aperture). My original thought that the camera is too big was soon forgotten. It may be larger than the S95, but carrying it around is significant lighter than carrying my 7D + lenses. The image quality is similar to the S95 however the ease of control, and DSLR likeness make it even even better. I am falling in love with the articulated display which makes shooting from strange angles possible. The screen alone has motivated me to make more creative photographs. I am disappointed that my S95 failed. For a second I considered buying another S95 but i'm so glad that i decided to go with this camera. The fact is that it will never fit in your pocket but in terms of a camera that needs to be with me when i dont feel like packing the DSLR + lenses + accessories, this camera does just fine. The only thing that I think could be improved is the camera's overall speed (i.e. burst shooting capability, auto focus speed, zoom response), but then again, maybe i have been spoiled but the speed of the 7D. Overall this is an excellent camera, i'm very happy i have it. It goes where the DSLR cant. It can't fit in a pocket but then again is there a great camera with all the controls of a DSLR that can?? Produces excellent images and videos. Its layout that puts all of its controls at your fingertips. And the articulated LCD has sparked my creativity. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
Pros: This camera is a perfect trade off between the limited capabilities of small "point and shoot" cameras and too bulky DSLRs. Takes beautiful photos, the low light / low noise capabilities are truly amazing - I have taken so many pictures that I never would have gotten because they are out of range of ANY flash - the flash rarely goes off when using the "P" program mode. If you were upset when you found out the pixel count fell, don't be - the resulting sensitivity is more than worth it.
I have owned a G6, G9, and now a G12 - I LOVE the Canon G series cameras. Just barely small enough to put in a hip / belt case and take with you - a camera is no good if it is in a camera bag in the trunk or back at the hotel! Video capablities are without equal in a package this size.
Co ... ns: More bulky than previous G series cameras and more plastic in the body. The G-9 had a metal body and was slimmer which made it more usefull as a wrist strap camera in a hip case.
Camera does not come with a wrist strap - the Canon WS-30 wrist strap is perfect for this camera. Shame on Canon for charging so much for them when bought through Canon parts dept.
I have a DSLR and several smaller point & shoot cameras - the Canon G series are my favorite. If you can see it this camera can photograph it - with quality. I prefered the G9's size and view screen, but this camera blows it away with better sensitivity and low noise. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: Amazing Camera at an even better price!
Item.Review: I bought this camera because I wanted a camera that can give me DSLR quality photos with a "travel friendly" size. I use this camera for backpacking both in the Mountains of Colorado and though Europe. As long as you are not looking for a megazoom, this camera is Great. The articulated screen is great for unique angles as well as self Portraits. I love how adjustable everything is on this camera, You have compete control over ISO and shutter speed to get exactly the shot you desire. Even if you don't know everything about photography, there are many preset modes that will give you great results. This camera will not let you down! ...

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I take this camera when I don't want to haul my heavy DSLR. it has all the manual controls and an excellent auto function when you just want that. The quality is excellent. I've taken some of my best photos with these Canon G series cameras. The swivel LCD screen lets you get up down and at odd angles for interesting shots. The wide angle lens is excellent for landscapes and cityscapes traveling and for family groups and activities. Controls are well placed. It's not small enough for pocket or purse but good for tote bag, briefcase, backpack or just carrying.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I was looking for a smaller sized camera as it is not always easy to grab an DSLR with multiple lenses. And I needed a small camera for tight places, i.e. airplane cockpits. G12 fit the bill...RAW files, 720P video, articulated LCD finder, manual control, stabilized 24-140 equivalent lens. However rear control wheel for selecting functions can be very touchy.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I purchased the G12 to use as a point and shoot for travel, holidays and birthdays. There are so many times that I need a camera, but I do not want to carry around my DSLR. I don't know how often you experience this, but when I pull out my DSLR, especially when its attached to a 70-200 f/2.8, people around me often say wow, look at that camera. In my attempt to avoid the attention and save my neck from carrying all the weight, I decided to purchase my first point and shoot. I know that photography is about compromise, but I was less willing to compromise, image quality, build, and handling as little as possible, while I was more willing to compromise overall size. First, the image quality is about the best you can get from a sensor of this size and the ability to shoot RAW allows you to g ... et even more out of your files. The camera feels solid in my hands without being too small for me to work the controls. I also generally prefer buttons over menu based controls. I didn't think I would care about the articulated screen, but as it turns out, it became one of my favorite features. Yes, its a little larger than some other compacts and almost as large as some m4/3 cameras with prime lens attached, but if I wanted an interchangeable lens camera I would just use m DSLR, it has better image quality anyway. I once has a cell phone that was so small that it was almost unusable because it was so difficult to hold and push the buttons. The G12 is not like that, it feels just right. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: I 'upgraded' from the g11 to the g12.
Item.Review:
Pros: It's handy; it's sturdy and can do it all
Cons: Lack of printed manual
The G12 is a very high-end an excellent Point and Shoot camera closer to D-SLR with flexible settings. It has all the features and benefits, I am looking for. I had bought a Canon Rebel but sold it as it was a bit too big for my taste and needs. Canon could have provided a written manual for the G12 but I found it easy enough to print the 212 page manual from the canon software on my own printer. I also bought a telephoto lens and adapter for filters as well; I feel I have it all without spending it all. The Canon S95 was a bit small for my handling.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I shot rangefinder Leica's for years, upgraded(?) to a 5D with good results but am currently blown away by the G12. Portability = useability, bottomline. The easily accessible exposure compensation dial is one of the features that enables images to be created in camera not in post with software. The essence of photography!The 'miniature effect' creates a horizontal or vertical focal plane which, once again, lets me create shallow depth of field, ala my f1.4 Leica lens, in camera. My favorite use of the G12, bar none, is the macro function. IT IS STUNNING! Flowers are prolific where I live and just by by chance and boredom one day I shot some tiny blooms and was absolutely shocked by the detail I saw when I viewed the images on my computer. The image stabilization plus the flip out LCD view ... finder makes handheld macro captures fairly easy with killer results. The only negative I've experienced so far is the lens cover blades began sticking halfway open and eventually I just removed them, got a semi-retro looking snap-over leather case and all is well now. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
Pros: Long battery life, fast, tactile body, affordable, and takes great pictures.
Cons: Not enough optical zoom for the money: only 5x
Love the G12. This is the 3rd Canon digital that I've purchased. I like the large LCD screen and the viewfinder. Too bad Canon is not putting the viewfinder on all of their cameras. In South Florida, it's not easy to see what you're photographing with the LCD screen only. Feels like an old 35mm camera. Not heavy; lithium ion battery lasts a long time without recharging. Little to no lag time between shots. Still learning what everything does.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I am an amateur photographer and recently aquired the G12 to use when I need to avoid the hassle of carrying all my bulky DSLR equipment around. I love the versatality of the G12, it offers me all the functions of my Canon 40D (and more)without the bulk. The swivel screen is a fantastic addition and very useful to capture images from obscure and interesting angles. The disadvantage of the small size is the proximity of all the controls to each other and the consequent tendency to press the wrong buttons. I find the carry strap annoying as it keeps swinging in the way. All in all, I can highly recommend this fine camera as a useful tool, for those moments when carrying your bulky DSLR and lenses is not feasible.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I purchased this camera because I was looking for a p&s that would take high quality images to rival a 40D with the 28-135 kit lens. This camera does a good job to that end. Ergonomically and functionally the camera is consistent with the Canon dSLR line. The index finger wheel and thumb-wheel are completely customizable, which allows the user complete control over the exposure settings. Additionally there is a programmable short-cut button, which allows even more control. The ISO control knob is nice, as is the exposure control knob. Noise at high ISO (greater than 1000) is an issue, but nothing a good NR plug-in cannot fix. I was unable to open G12 RAW images with Adobe Photoshop CS4; Adobe Camera RAW v6.2 is only compatible with CS5 (NOT CS4, CS3, etc.). The bundled Canon so ... ftware works fine for this and there are other work-arounds (like Adobe's free RAW-to-DNG converter). In terms of video it does 720p 24fps. The downside is that the focal length available is limited by the focal length at the start of the video capture. For example, if you start at 3x zoom, you may zoom in to 5x (and have all the digital zoom available), but you will not be able to go any wider than the original 3x. Also once you lock focus in video and start recording - that focus cannot be changed after the fact. There is no manual focus in video mode. In short no one will use this as a very serious video camera, but video itself is of good quality. The camera has many bells & whistles like Miniature mode (faux tilt-shift); HDR (built-in); Fish-eye lens effect; ect. These things are neat, but seem to be intended for the consumer market. The lens is sharp, but not fast (f/2.8-f/4.5). At the end of the day the camera takes very nice images and video. It's light, but still a little bulky for most pockets. I carry it whenever I'm not carrying my regular bag. The battery life is good and hasn't been an issue in the two weeks I've used it. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I am a professional photographer and use the best Canon L lenses and bodies made. That said, sometimes I want something that is much smaller and fun. A camera that takes great images, let's me shoot auto or manual and is pocket size. I find I get great photos I would normally miss because I actually have the camera on my person. The G12 is an amazing little camera. Not as small as some point and shoots but still pocket sized. Very sharp images, very good in low light, excellent focus, shoots RAW, has an adjustable flash which is a HUGE benefit, Great battery life. Macro is decent. Accurate metering. I do not like the flash when shooting wide angle closer than 4 feet because the coverage is a bit narrowly focused and creates a vignette. I also do not like the flash unless it is diale ... d back -1 to -1.3 as it tends to blow out faces shot close up in a dark room. But once dialed back, the images are perfect. That said, buy this camera. You will see a lot of pros using this one on their vacation. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: The thing that sold me on this over s95 was the control dial in front for aperture and the range finder like top dials. I have had point and shoots where I had to scroll through the screen menu to change settings and swore I would not go through that again. Yes, you can't slip into your pocket. Reviews touting its control of DOF is what ultimately set the hook. Range of zoom seems pretty nice and the camera response is pretty good as well. The macro on this camera is really quite nice. Images seem pretty detail rich. If this is any indication of lens quality, I would have to say it's at least as good as the better non-L lenses. The one thing I would caution, is to keep your ISO around 400 if possible. Getting up towards 800 you introduce noise to the point that you are reminded, oh yeah ... , a point and shoot camera. The fact that the top dial has 1/3 stop increments is a really nice feature and does let you control noise. Coupled with the front dial aperture control makes for a nice quick little camera. Lag time not withstanding. Seems inherent in the P&S range of cameras. I like the swing out screen and have found it useful for shooting in awkward and cramped situations. The screen itself seems more prone to fingerprints that are not easy to remove. Overall camera build seems quite good. I like it's weight and it actually feels pretty sturdy for its size. For me, this camera will not replace packing your SLR for an important shoot. It is a convenient and powerful little AIO camera that can create some great images. Canon has done a great job of putting the features that are most important right up on top, and ready to go. Nice One! expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: Canon continues to improve the G1x line with the G12. I bought this for my wife for as a present and was tempted to keep it for myself. It is small, relatively light-weight, compared to a DSLR, but packed with features, and a solid feel in your hands. It takes great pictures just using the Program mode, which I am sure will get better using non-auto and RAW captures. Now I know why most pros have one of these so they always have a good camera handy. The only complaint I have is that Canon does not included a printed manual. I had to print one off of the CD for my wife. However, I did get her the G12 cheatsheet from PhotoBert - also great products.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I'm just learning about this camera, but, getting great shots & it has so many features. I like the swing out LCD screen & how the controls pop up on the screen to tell what you need to know about them. I like the size especially. Small, but, powerful.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: Needed a small camera will maximum features and photo quality. I'm a Nikon pro but prefer the performance of the Canon P&S cameras. battery life in my opinion is a bit short but with flash using the same battery,,,you can expect only so much from the size & technology. The size allows for more unobtrusive people photography and portability especially when I don't want to tote around a pro camera all day. Can't beat the features & photo quality for the price in my opinion.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: a nice substitute to dslr on the road
Item.Review: I am most of time dSLR user, need a smaller size camera for outdoor trips. The G12 is nicely built with many manual controls. The flexible LCD screen is a nice feature. The picture quality is excellent.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: Packed with features, well designed ergonomics, good quality photos, fits nicely between SLRs and pocket point and shoots, video works nicely. It's the one camera to carry around when you can only have one.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
Pros: Good Image Quality; Large Clear LCD; Good Image Stabilization; Fast/accurate auto-focus
Bought the G10 for work and was always happy with it. Bought the G12 for home - wife already liked the G10. Great quality, solid build.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: Camera is good. Rock-solid body. Very clean images, simple, intuitive interface. Quick to pull out and shoot with. Biggest con is that the flash only has low, medium, and high power - I'd like to be able to set flash settings in EV +/- steps just like exposure. I still can't seem to get the flash to expose correctly as a result. The RAW format has changed again, and consequently, doesn't work with Photoshop RAW or Adobe DNG converter. Those should be updating soon to accommodate, but for how, I'm stuck using Canon's slow less-good DPP software to edit the RAW files.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: use the product as a pocket take everywhere camera the menus and the scene variations are so much fun to use. the camera was surprisingly fast and generally flexible. the i.s. is great. have had early power shot cameras (not the g series) and for me this is worth the difference. the articulated screen is useful for sneaky shots. the raw files and the choice jpg images are fabulous as well. love this camera. if this camera came with a bigger sensor oh boy. large blowups are not as good as aps/full frame as to be expected.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
Pros: Fast/accurate auto-focus; Good Image Stabilization; Good Image Quality; Large Clear LCD; Good in Low Light
This is the 2nd G12 I have owned. Image quality is unsurpassed and you have complete and easily accessible control over most features of the camera which are to numerous to mention. While it won't fit in a shirt or jeans pocket it fits quite easily in my cargo shorts pockets and I carry it with me most of the time I don't want to lug by 7D DSLR around. I lose little in image quality between the two cameras.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I have been photographing for many years as both professional and enthusiast with Leica's, Hasselblad's and Nikon's, and I am continually amazed at the image quality from the Canon G12, even from its jpegs (RAW is very impressive). I typically photograph with both formats, jpg and RAW, and save times are typically three seconds at most--not inconvenient but not instant either. Startup is very fast with the G12, AF is accurate, and the close-up capabilities are crisply impressive at wide-angle. Lens flare is virtually non-existent, image contrast is very high, sharpness is excellent, noise is extremely well controlled, and chromatic aberrations are hard to find (and easily corrected with software). I'd previously owned a G9, which was notable, but the G12 blows it away. I've also owned the ... Panasonic ZS7, which the G12 leaves in the dust, and own an Olympus E-P2, which G12 images compare favorably with although not as detailed. Even when printing at 13 x 18 inches the G12 results are surprisingly nuanced and detailed with little or no noise (ISO 80-200). Needless to say, I'm very happy with the results. I think it's Canon best G series to date.MOVIES: AF (continuous), AE Lock, and Exposure Compensation ARE NOT AVAILABLE in movie mode! In other words whichever focus point you began with when you started shooting is exactly where the camera will remain for the remainder of that video. No, you can't begin with a close-up and then shift to focus on something far. The AF won't work. Which is dumb. A huge disappointment from Canon for those interested in video! I hope they fix this with a firmware update.SOFTWARE: The included Canon Digital Photo Professional software does a great job of converting RAW files into 16-bit or 8-bit Tiff, including manipulating the parameters for Unsharp Mask, and notates the RAW file so that your settings can be recalled when re-opened. It also lets you adjust White Balance, Contrast, Tone Curve, Saturation, Sharpness, Noise, Crop, etc. While it doesn't have the finesse of controls in Adobe Camera Raw (Adobe Bridge) it does a very good job, including Batch processing. HANDLING: I found the handling and heft of the Canon G12 to be very comfortable, especially in using the swivel-tilt LCD screen (which is very sharp, by the way). The knurled ring on the front just below the shutter/zoom button (which allows you to adjust shutter speed of aperture, depending on Mode) is very useful, although I times I found it too easy to mistake it for the zoom control.Infrequently I found myself wishing that the zoom range was a bit longer, perhaps 28 to 200mm. But realistically I think Canon's decision to limit the zoom range to 28-140mm (more than enough for most situations) is probably one of the factors that makes the lens such an outstanding performer. The Canon G12 is a great little camera that tries to compete with Micro Four Thirds and blows point-and-shoots out of the water. expand » « collapse

Item.Review:
Pros: Swivel-Tilt Screen; Easy To Use; Good Image Stabilization; Large Clear LCD; Good Image Quality; Short Lag Time; Fast/accurate auto-focus
Cons: No continuous AF in video
I have been photographing for many years as both professional and enthusiast with Canon's, Leica's, Hasselblad's and Nikon's, and I am continually amazed at the image quality from the Canon G12, even from its jpegs (RAW is very impressive). I typically photograph with both formats, jpg and RAW, and save times are typically three seconds at most--not inconvenient but not instant either. Startup is very fast with the G12, AF is accurate, and the close-up capabilities are crisply impressive at wide-angle. Even when printing at 13 x 18 inches the G12 results are surprisingly nuanced and detailed with little or no noise (ISO 80-200). Needless to say, I'm very happy with the results. MOVIES: AF (continuous), AE Lock, and Exposure Compensation ARE NOT AVAILABLE in movie mode! In other words whichever focus point you began with when you started shooting is exactly where the camera will remain for the remainder of that video. No, you can't begin with a close-up and then shift to focus on something far. The AF won't work. Which is dumb. A huge disappointment from Canon for those interested in video! It also lets you adjust White Balance, Contrast, Tone Curve, Saturation, Sharpness, Noise, Crop, etc. While it doesn't have the finesse of controls in Adobe Camera Raw (Adobe Bridge) it does a very good job, including Batch processing.

The knurled ring on the front just below the shutter/zoom button (which allows you to adjust shutter speed of aperture, depending on Mode) is very useful, although I times I found it too easy to mistake it for the zoom control.
Infrequently I found myself wishing that the zoom range was a bit longer, perhaps 28 to 200mm. But realistically I think Canon's decision to limit the zoom range to 28-140mm (more than enough for most situations) is probably one of the factors that makes the lens such an outstanding performer. The Canon G12 is a great little camera that tries to compete with Micro Four Thirds and blows point-and-shoots out of the water. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I bought this camera as an upgrade to a canon g10 that I was super happy with for the past two years but wanted better low light performance. This camera definitely delivered in that respect. Where I was only able to shoot at iso400 before I can now fully utilize 800 and even 1600 (with expected noise) for ambient light images. I'm really impressed with the image quality as well. My only issues thus far are that focusing on distant landscapes at infinity is no where near as fast as the g10. The camera will give you a yellow box warning stating that it can't focus even in mid day light. It requires you to find something contrasty on the horizon to focus on before recomposing to shoot. I've been quite disappointed with this as well as close up macro focusing. Just not as fast as previous mod ... el. My second issue is that the new screen on the back is bulky and takes up precious hand grip area... I prefered the flush mount screen of the g10. Overall the quality if the images outweigh the quirks. This is an awesome camera to surest into your pocket or throw into a slr camera bag as a backup. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I replaced my Canon G9 with the new G12. I had purchased an aftermarket knurled grip for the G9, and I am happy that Canon devised a better finger grip for the newer series. I love the rugged feel of the frame around the swing out screen. Seems rugged. So many of the features are so familiar to me from the older G series that I am right at home. The facial recognition is nice for party pix. The slow-sync shutter creates much more natural lighting for flash photography. This is still my favorite camera, though I have a truly pocket-size S90 as well as a 30D and 50D as my SLR's. You won't be disappointed with the G12, unless you are looking for something to fit in your pocket instead of your cargo pants.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: Love it! Almost everything i want
Item.Review: The new G12 is a great point and shoot and although my main camera is a 1D, this is small enough for me to carry everywhere without putting my back out. The large flip out screen is something i never thought I'd use, but am now using all the time. I'm so used to looking through a viewfinder that it took a little getting used to but is great allowing high and low shots with ease and big enough to see everything clearly. All the presets are easy to use and the miniature effect is already a favorite. The low light function works well and all the dials using it in manual setting are great. That said manual focus option is extremely fiddly and annoying to use and takes forever to get the right focus. Would be great to have a ring focus on the viewfinder but this wouldn't be for everyone. ... I'm also having a lot of trouble importing the RAW files into my computer even with the provided software...i'm sure it's a mac thing and everything will catch up sooner or later. Other than that a very happy customer! Keep up the good work. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I am a photographer, but don't want to carry my 5D to the zoo and ball games!! This is great to leave in my purse. Takes wonderful, spontaneous photos, even on Auto. Focus is incredible! I'm getting a little spoiled by it in fact. Downsides? Viewfinder is poor. Shot in RAW and could'nt open the files in Bridge. Contacted Canon and they said there wasn't an update for the RAW files yet and I would have to open those in their software... which I don't llike. Also, recycle time is a little slow, maybe not as much if you use the viewfinder and not the screen.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: Nice camera, but a little overpriced
Item.Review: Overall, I think the G12 is a nice camera. My last Canon G-Series was a G2, which I really liked. Since the G2, I've mainly use Panasonic FZ series digital compacts, because of the high-quality Leica lenses, the zoom range, the ability to achieve focus quickly, and the intuitive controls. I made the switch to the G12 because I wanted better quality from high-ISO images, decent manual controls, and the capability to take HD movies. The good??? The camera produces very nice images that I have no doubt will allow printing up to 12x18 at near the quality of my D300. The images at ISO 100 and 200 are very clean, and ISO 400 is completely usable. The lens has a little bit of distortion (mainly at the wide end), but it is very sharp. Also, the zoom range is fairly decent. The camera feel ... s nice in-hand, and has all of the main controls very accessible.The bad??? My main gripe has to do with the build quality and the price. The build quality is definitely nice, but it doesn't feel as nice as what a [$] compact should provide. It really should have an all metal body in this price range (only the front plate is metal). Also, some of the dials feel a little cheap. The other gripe has to do with the controls. As you adjust aperture/shutter speed/ISO/etc., the camera feels a bit sluggish to respond. It's not as fast as my 2 year old Panasonic. It's also not a speed demon when it comes to focusing. It takes about ?? to 1 sec to focus in good light. It's not bad, but I was hoping for closer to DSLR-speed for a high-end compact camera in the $500 price range. The battery charge indicator isn't very useful ??? it goes from full charge (three bars) to dead in about 10 minutes of actual use. However, this syndrome is pretty common with digital compacts. The tripod hole is not centered with lens axis. Lastly, the optical finder is almost useless.Sorry, no ugly??? it's a good looking camera with very intuitive controls.Because of the build quality and the sluggish controls, I'm left just a bit disappointed. I would probably be satisfied had I only paid $400 for this camera. Despite this, I will still enjoy the nice images that can be produced using this camera. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I was surprised by the high quality of the photo this portable camera took. There is a lot of manual functions help me to achieve the DSLR can do. The size is little bigger than small pokcet camera. The video is OK and there is no autofocus during zooming.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review:
Pros: Good in Low Light; Easy To Use; Good Image Stabilization; Small / Compact
I had been searching for a camera whose screen could be tilted 360 degree. Onlly SX40 and G12 fitted by budget and POINT-and-Shoot category.
I loved the antique look and chose G12 and am really happy with the product I chose.
I am merely a casual photographer and the only cons I have seen in last 2 weeks is, in AUTO mode, the FLASH comes on even in evening light. You have to manually switch-off the flash if you'd like to capture an instant in evening light.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: Great Compact Camera Full of Features.
Item.Review: Point and shoot street camera Light weight travel camera Great Battery Life I like all the manual overide options for control of image. I own a G10 (prior version) and use it daily for documentation at work so I wanted a new travel camera and looked no farther than the Canon PowerShot G12

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I travel quite frequently and always have trouble packing my DSLR. The Canon G12 is perfect for on the go photo and video. And it fits easily inside my carry on bag. I prefer this over the Canon S95 because it have more external controls which makes it easier to change settings between shots.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.Review: I bought this for a first time trip to South Africa. It takes beautiful pictures, stunning HD videos and is so simple to use! I guess there are people who like to fool with manual adjustments. But on auto my shots came out great. I should have purchased a telephoto lens with it, maybe a 24x. The 5x is OK but is not OK for distance shots. My fault, not the camera's. I got an additional battery pack which was smart and took three 8 gig cards. Check out the videos at hwh1946. Lots of bumps from the RangeRover and the wind. But check out the quality of the film.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot G12 10 MP Digital Camera
Item.ReviewTitle: Cannon PowerShot G12 - overpriced but OK
Item.Review: Being a previous PowerShot (A640) owner, I want several features on my camera. Thankfully Canon kept the viewfinder and the Screen that can be manipulated 180 degrees (this really protects the screen from scratches when not in use and also allows me to see shots at angles I normally would have had to shoot blindly.) The feature they got rid of, to my great disappointment, was the ability to use alkaline batteries. I never had to worry about not having charged batteries as the AA batteries were available wherever I was at.
